Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Workshop on Acquiring and Sharing Data Within the CMMI Research Community; Arlington, Virginia; December 7-8, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ever increasing need for a robust and reliable infrastructure for the curation, storage and sharing of research data has been identified across multiple disciplines. While the needs of different research communities will vary, there are many issues which the Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation communities will have in common for data infrastructure. This award supports a workshop which brings these communities together to identify these needs, learn from the success of communities whose data infrastructures are further advanced, and plan for paths forward in establishing the tools, resources, and culture shifts needed to bring open sharing of research data to the broad engineering community.

The workshop supported by this award will highlight the key issues that must be addressed to realize the full impact and use of big data on the research areas represented in the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation (CMMI) at the National Science Foundation. The community will convene to (1) develop an overall strategy and short term research agenda for capturing and sharing large volumes of data (2) recommend methods and techniques for making large data sets available and usable by the CMMI research communities (3) forge interdisciplinary research teams that can develop prototype platforms for CMMI research communities and (4) suggest best practices for NSF data management plans. Approximately 60 members of the community, including both junior and senior researchers, data scientists, library scientists, and members of the scientific publishing community will convene in Arlington, VA at NSF Headquarters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported a workshop that brought together the CMMI research community to develop a strategy for the collection, curation and sharing or research data. CMMI research focuses on urban infrastructure systems, the built environment, natural disasters, manufacturing and material science. The workshop was help in Arlington, Virginia in February 2017. Workshop participants included civil engineers, data scientists, material scientists, urban planners, publishers, and representatives of relevant government agencies and professional organizations. Data sharing repositories have been shown to increase research productivity, improve research validity and increase the rate of new knowledge creation in other research fields. Data repositories also allow researchers to combine data from multiple studies to test new hypotheses and support new forms of analysis. This workshop produced a strategic roadmap and phased timeline to develop data sharing platforms to support the CMMI research community. Workshop participants learned how data sharing repositories have been developed, used and supported by other research communities. Workshop participants identified a number of alternative funding models for data repositories and assessed the strengths and weaknesses of each model. The workshop report has stimulated interest in data sharing within the CMMI community. It has initiated discussions about how to incentivize data sharing within this research community. It has also contributed to internal discussions within CMMI and CISE on data repositories and the reuse of scientific data. It also contributed to the revision of guidelines on how Data management Plans are developed, used and evaluated.
